awd_titl_txt: An Innovative Bridge Program for Mentoring BS-MS Fast-Track Students towards PhDs in Mathematical Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
The Mathematics Department at the University of Texas Arlington will run a three-year bridge project involving 30 students to transition them to doctoral programs in the mathematical sciences. The targeted students are those, especially from underrepresented or underserved groups, who are not yet as competitive for doctoral programs as those who already had strong preparation in analysis and advanced linear algebra. The project is intended to be a comprehensive support system that benefits from the existing mathematics learning community in the mathematics doctoral program at the University of Texas Arlington and faculty mentoring and peer mentoring. This project will provide participating students with the opportunity to develop their full intellectual and academic potential in the mathematical sciences, by providing them with a comprehensive preparation and an innovative curricular and training program that emphasizes transition from an undergraduate program to a comprehensive PhD program. By addressing critical issues related to transition to doctoral studies in the mathematical sciences, particularly for those from underrepresented or underserved groups, the project has the potential to contribute to a significant increase in the quantity, quality, and diversity of the future leaders in the mathematical sciences, by serving as a model program for other institutions or other Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) fields. This project has also the potential to impact curriculum improvements in the undergraduate mathematical training in underserved institutions in the nation through collaboration with institutions offering doctoral programs, benefiting both parties. By addressing critical issues related to transition to doctoral studies in the mathematical sciences, particularly for those from underrepresented or underserved groups, the project also has the potential to contribute to a significant increase in the quantity, quality, and diversity of the future leaders in the mathematical sciences. This project has also the potential to impact curriculum improvements in the undergraduate mathematical training in underserved institutions in the nation through collaboration with institutions offering doctoral programs, benefiting both parties.

This three-year project aims at increasing the quality and quantity of US doctoral students in the mathematical sciences, particularly those among underrepresented or underserved groups, through strong mentoring and a bridge-to-doctorate program with a BS-MS fast-track component. It targets those talented students among underrepresented groups or from small colleges or minority serving institutions, who are not yet considered competitive for rigorous national doctoral programs due to deficiency especially in analysis and advanced linear algebra. The project aims to train and mentor the participating students to make them well prepared in analysis and advanced linear algebra and to become competitive for a comprehensive PhD program in Mathematical Sciences. The project builds on two cornerstones: (1) a bridge-to-doctorate program with a BS-MS fast track that focuses on students in transition from undergraduate to graduate programs to strengthen their background in analysis and advanced linear algebra, and (2) a comprehensive system for such students providing strong mentoring and aggressive recruitment in the Gulf States Math Alliance, a regional branch of the National Alliance for Doctoral Studies in the Mathematical Sciences covering the states of Texas, Louisiana, and Mississippi.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF project "An Innovative Bridge Program for Mentoring BS-MS Fast-Track Students towards PhDs in Mathematical Sciences" (Bridge program, DMS-1620630; 9/12/2016-8/30/2022) at the Department of Mathematics, University of Texas at Arlington (UTA), was directed by a faculty team consisting of Professors Jianzhong Su (Bridge Project Director/PI, Math Department Chair), co-PIs Tuncay Aktosun (Bridge Program Director),  David Jorgensen, Ren-cang Li, Theresa Jorgensen, and senior personnel Hristo Kojouharov (Math Graduate Director).

 

The Bridge program aims to transform the participating students into strong candidates for standard Ph.D. programs in the mathematical sciences with graduate assistantships. The program consists of a one-year academic preparation to strengthen mathematical background for doctoral studies and the mentoring component preparing the participants for doctoral studies. The targeted students are those with potential, talent, and commitment to achieve a doctoral degree, but not yet ready to succeed in a standard Ph.D. program for reasons such as coming from an underserved institution, where advanced mathematics courses may not be available.

 

The Bridge Program has been outstanding in preparing the participants for doctoral studies. It has also had strong positive effects on the UTA Mathematics Graduate program itself, by creating a better academic environment for beginning graduate students, for retention, for preparation for academic or nonacademic careers, involvement in outreach activities for younger students, and functioning as mentors or peer mentors. The program has also helped with the DEI (diversity, equity, and inclusion) in UTA Math graduate program, where all students work in harmony and in a supporting environment, and where their intrinsic qualities and talents are maximally utilized. Some of the program elements have contributed the success:

1. A student participates in the Bridge Program for an entire academic year. The cohort size may vary each year (originally designed for 3 cohorts of 10 students each year, but resulted in a total of 42 students during 2016-2022). The program focuses on URM (underrepresented minority) and other underserved students, especially from HBCUs (Historical Black Colleges and Universities) and HSIs (Hispanic Serving Institutions). It is different from a typical post-bac program in the sense that it offers individualized curriculum and advising based on students' needs and strengths, and it helps the participants move forward without delay in progression towards doctoral studies.

2. The Bridge Program has a set of best practices in curriculum to transition students into doctoral programs by strengthening foundation in Analysis and Linear Algebra, and offers other graduate level courses and research opportunities for students' academic progression and professional development.  

3. The program has dedicated support from 25 HBCUs and HSIs in GSMath (Gulf States Math Alliance). In return, the Bridge Program serves as a backbone for GSMath mentoring activities, and it has already sponsored and organized/or co-organized 6 annual GSMath conferences since 2017.

4. The Bridge Program provides a vibrant and immersive learning environment within a Ph.D. program, where Bridge fellows collaborate not only among themselves but also work side by side with other Ph.D. students. This ensures academic success, learning about an entire doctoral program, and peer support.

 

The project at UTA has supported 42 students in 6 cohorts, including 21 women and 21 URMs; 94% of the fellows have been admitted to PhD/MS programs. Intellectual Merit: Students have engaged in research, graduate course work and advance STEM knowledge in their professional careers. At the end of the project in August 2022, six (6) Bridge fellows have completed their original research and earned doctoral degree in Mathematics.  Broader Impacts: Mentoring and individual course planning have become a part of departmental practice at the Department of Mathematics in the University of Texas at Arlington, academic support for graduate students has improved, and an effective recruitment and a strong mentoring network have been established within GSMath also through the annual Gulf States Math Alliance conferences which have been participated by a total of 813 students, faculty, staff and administrators from at least 47 universities, colleges and organizations over the 6 years during the grant period.

 

On October 19, 2022, The American Mathematical Society honored the Math Bridge to Doctorate Program at the University of Texas at Arlington (UTA) Mathematics Department with the 2023 Mathematics Programs That Make a Difference Award. This annual AMS award recognizes programs that increase the number of students from historically underrepresented groups who receive advanced mathematical degrees. Examples of such groups include racial and ethnic minorities, women, low-income students, and first-generation college students. The  American Mathematical Society award citation credits "UTA's Math Bridge to Doctorate Program meets all three criteria for the Mathematics Programs That Make a Difference Award: It contributes to an increase of students from historically underrepresented groups who receive advanced mathematical degrees, has documented success, and is a replicable model".

The American Mathematical Society news release is in https://www.ams.org/news?news_id=7106.
